item.title: Ticket #734 (Problem with get_linksbyname) updated
item.dc:creator: Manzabar
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #734 (Problem with get_linksbyname) created
item.dc:creator: Manzabar
item.description:
When get_linksbyname generates a links from WordPress's Link Manager and said link contains an ampersand; it writes that ampersand as &#038;

For instance, a link to: ​http://ctrlaltdel-online.com/index.php?t=archives&date=last

Gets written as: ​http://ctrlaltdel-online.com/index.php?t=archives&date=last

item.title: Ticket #733 (check_comment is too rigid) updated
item.dc:creator: skippy
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #733 (check_comment is too rigid) created
item.dc:creator: skippy
item.description: The function check_comment immediately returns a false value if manual moderation is in effect. This severely limits the usability of this function in plugins designed to work with or without manual moderation.

item.title: Ticket #732 (Dates in RSS2 are generated improperly) updated
item.dc:creator: rq
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #732 (Dates in RSS2 are generated improperly) created
item.dc:creator: rq
item.description: Post dates in RSS2 are generated with respect to locale settings. IMHO, this is a bug, because not every app can understand Lithuanian dates, for example. I think, the dates should be generated with respect to RFC-2822 instead of locale.

item.title: Ticket #731 (the_title() fed to JavaScript deletion confirmation should be sanitized) updated
item.dc:creator: morganiq
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #731 (the_title() fed to JavaScript deletion confirmation should be sanitized) created
item.dc:creator: morganiq
item.description:
Filters which add HTML containing attributes to the_title() can break the JavaScript deletion confirmations on edit.php.

This can fail two ways:

  1. With double-quoted attributes, the onclick attribute is ended at the first double-quote and the remainder of the tag's text is output to the page.
  2. With single-quoted attributes, the JavaScript produces a syntax error, which causes some browsers to ignore it and continue visiting the link, resulting in an unconfirmed deletion.

Suggest adding strip_tags().

item.title: Ticket #522 (admin cannot edit pages created by a lower user) updated
item.dc:creator: mdawaffe
item.description:
wp-includes/edi-pages.php line 12

I'm not sure what the if statement is checking for; it isn't clear to me why $user_ID wouldn't be set when someone is viewing this page.

That said, here's a patch which allows a user to list all the pages owned by: him/herself and users with a strictly lower user_level

At least it worked for me.

item.title: Ticket #602 (URI Problems) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description:
I think it should be the other way around. Run the siteurl updater code only if RELOCATE is defined. Moving the site is rare. Setting RELOCATE in order to update the siteurl isn't too onerous and is certainly better than having to go through phpMyAdmin (especially if it's not available). However, loading wp-login is not rare. Having to define two constants to prevent siteurl reset (and having to go into phpMyAdmin to fix it) is onerous. I expect many people will have to set WPADDRESS and BLOGADDRESS, whereas few people will have to set RELOCATE.

So, in wp-config.php:

Uncomment this to reset your siteurl in the event that you move your blog. define('RELOCATE', true);

In wp-login.php:

if (defined('RELOCATE')) { WordPress has moved. Reset the siteurl. if ( isset( $_SERVERPATH_INFO? ) && ($_SERVERPATH_INFO? != $_SERVERPHP_SELF?) )

$_SERVERPHP_SELF? = str_replace( $_SERVERPATH_INFO?, , $_SERVERPHP_SELF? );

if ( dirname('​http://' . $_SERVERHTTP_HOST? . $_SERVERPHP_SELF?) != get_settings('siteurl') )

update_option('siteurl', dirname('​http://' . $_SERVERHTTP_HOST? . $_SERVERPHP_SELF?) );

}

item.title: Ticket #726 (atom feed not identified as feed by is_feed()) updated
item.dc:creator: steph-tara
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #726 (atom feed not identified as feed by is_feed()) created
item.dc:creator: steph-tara
item.description:
filter function on the_content (sticking technorati tags at the end of content) is not being activated in atom feed, while it is for the rss feed.

function:

function append_tags($content) {

if (is_feed()) {

$tags_list=get_bunny_tags_list(); $content.=$tags_list;

} return $content;

}

hooked:

add_filter('the_content', 'append_tags');

Seems that the variable identifying the atom feed page as "feed" is not being set correctly.

item.title: Ticket #723 (Other's Drafts should not repeat your drafts) updated
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description:
Better yet, don't even perform the other_drafts query if there are no other authors on the blog that the author can edit.

Patch attached [otherdraft2_edit.php], run against wp-admin/edit.php v1.39

item.title: Ticket #723 (Other's Drafts should not repeat your drafts) updated
item.dc:creator: coffee2code
item.description:
In getting the initial value for $editable, WP has already performed a query that includes post_author != $user_ID. The problem is that if this is a 1-author blog (the admin, user_ID == "1"), $editable will receive an empty initial value. The next line of code makes $editable an array with the single element of "1" if $editable was empty, essentially adding the admin back into the mix as a potential "other draft". A fix would be to simply turn an empty $editable into an empty array instead of an array with an element of "1".

Patch attached [otherdraft_edit.php], run against wp-admin/edit.php v1.39.

item.title: Ticket #723 (Other's Drafts should not repeat your drafts) updated
item.dc:creator: jesuit
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #723 (Other's Drafts should not repeat your drafts) created
item.dc:creator: jesuit
item.description:
On the edit.php page the logged in users drafts show up in both Your Drafts as well as Other's Drafts.

Obviously your drafts should not show up as Other's drafts. Adding AND post_author != $user_ID to the end of the sql select statement for $other_drafts will fix this.

item.title: Ticket #721 (WP should not use cache-control: no-store) updated
item.dc:creator: Jesse Ruderman
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #721 (WP should not use cache-control: no-store) created
item.dc:creator: Jesse Ruderman
item.description:
Wordpress uses cache-control: no-store on most pages, including the front page of my WP blog. This causes Firefox to not cache the page even for the purpose of using the Back button. As a result, going Back to a Wordpress blog is slow, loses the scroll position, and loses form content.

I assume the intent is not to ensure that users see the newest version when they hit the Back button (that isn't worth the slowness and disorientation), but to ensure that visitors see the newest version when they click a link or bookmark to a blog they have visited recently. I think that can be accomplished using some combination of no-cache (not no-store), must-revalidate, and expires.

item.title: Ticket #720 (RSS feeds currently do not validate) updated
item.dc:creator: saadiq
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #720 (RSS feeds currently do not validate) created
item.dc:creator: saadiq
item.description:
It seems that the_excerpt_rss() no longer escapes html characters regardless of what parameters it is passed. As such, if you have those characters or html in your excerpt then some news readers will balk on your invalid feed.

I've fixed it on my site by adding CDATA tags to the description elements of the rss feeds and to the summary tag of the atom feed.
